claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers must exchange dollars for euros when visiting.

attacks.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers must exchange dollars for euros when visiting.
Many travelers use credit cards or digital payment methods that automatically handle currency conversion, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Some credit cards charge high foreign transaction fees, making physical currency exchange more economical for frequent or large transactions.
Currency exchange services at airports or tourist areas often have unfavorable rates, making it better to exchange money before traveling or using ATMs.
Pre-travel currency exchange can be inconvenient or unavailable in some regions, forcing travelers to rely on in-country exchange services.

supporting.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, so travelers must exchange dollars for krone when visiting.

attacks.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, so travelers must exchange dollars for krone when visiting.
Many businesses in Denmark accept euros, especially in tourist areas, reducing the need to exchange dollars for krone.
Acceptance of euros in Denmark is limited and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates, making it impractical for most transactions.
Travelers can use credit or debit cards for most transactions in Denmark, avoiding the need for physical currency exchange.
Some small businesses and rural areas in Denmark may not accept cards, requiring travelers to carry krone for certain purchases.

supporting.text: The euro is the only legal tender in France, making currency exchange necessary for dollar holders.

attacks.text: The euro is the only legal tender in France, making currency exchange necessary for dollar holders.
Many places in France, especially tourist areas, accept major credit cards, reducing the immediate need for currency exchange.
Credit card transactions often incur foreign exchange fees, making local currency exchange still preferable for cost-sensitive travelers.
Some businesses in France may accept USD informally, though at unfavorable exchange rates.
Informal USD acceptance is rare and unreliable, and violates EU financial regulations.

supporting.text: The Danish krone is the only legal tender in Denmark, making currency exchange necessary for dollar holders.

attacks.text: The Danish krone is the only legal tender in Denmark, making currency exchange necessary for dollar holders.
Many businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, accept euros despite the official currency being the krone.
Acceptance of euros in Denmark is limited and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates, reinforcing the need for krone.
Some Danish banks and ATMs allow direct withdrawal in dollars, bypassing the need for immediate krone exchange.
Direct dollar withdrawals in Denmark are rare and typically incur high fees, making currency exchange more practical.

supporting.text: Neither France nor Denmark accepts the US dollar as legal tender, requiring currency exchange for transactions.

attacks.text: Neither France nor Denmark accepts the US dollar as legal tender, requiring currency exchange for transactions.
Some businesses in tourist-heavy areas of France and Denmark may unofficially accept US dollars, though not as legal tender.
Even if some businesses unofficially accept dollars, this is rare and not reliable for general transactions, reinforcing the need for currency exchange.
Denmark uses the krone, not the euro, so travelers must exchange dollars into two different currencies, not just euros.
While Denmark uses the krone, many businesses in major cities also accept euros, reducing the need for immediate krone exchange.

supporting.text: Currency exchange is mandatory for dollar holders in both France and Denmark due to their distinct national currencies.

attacks.text: Currency exchange is mandatory for dollar holders in both France and Denmark due to their distinct national currencies.
Many businesses in tourist-heavy areas of France and Denmark accept US dollars directly, reducing the need for mandatory currency exchange.
Accepting US dollars is often at unfavorable exchange rates, making currency exchange still economically necessary for dollar holders.
Digital payment methods like credit cards and mobile wallets automatically handle currency conversion, bypassing the need for physical exchange.
Some merchants or small businesses may not accept digital payments, requiring physical currency exchange for transactions.
